metadata.title: The Photoelectrochemical Response of a β-Carotene Coated Hematite Nanoarchitecture Biophotoelectrode with Cauliflower and Nano Octahedron Types Morphologies

sections.text:
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 166 (12) H541-H548 (2019) H541 0013-4651/2019/166(12)/H541/8/$38.00 © The Electrochemical Society
The Photoelectrochemical Response of a β-Carotene Coated Hematite Nanoarchitecture Biophotoelectrode with Cauliflower and Nano Octahedron Types Morphologies Purvika Agarwal and Debajeet K. Bora z
Centre for Nano and Material Sciences, JAIN University, Jain Global Campus, Bengaluru, 562112 Karnataka, India
The enhanced performance of the semiconductor electrode for photoelectrochemical water splitting with the coating of a readily available biomolecule such as the β-Carotene could be the next design of bio photoelectrode. In this work, how the β-Carotene coating on a hematite photoelectrode enhanced the performance of photoelectrochemical response has been described. For the same, a one-pot material chemistry route is described here, with which hematite photoelectrode with combined morphologies of the octahedron and cauliflower type can be obtained. The primary significance of the work is that the β-Carotene coating of hematite cauliflower helps in getting a two-fold enhancement in the photocurrent density in comparison to the uncoated one. Though there are many reports about this type of improvement, however, from the cost wise perspective, the isolated β-Carotene pigment coating and its performance in the current study are better. Also, other main physicochemical prospects are that the β-Carotene coating helps in removing the cathodic transient spike obtained in a transient photocurrent measurement for an uncoated hematite cauliflower. It signifies the electron donating action of β-Carotene to prevent excitonic recombination for this kind of new bio photoelectrode design. In addition to this, the octahedron morphologies with the β-Carotene coating also shows similar enhancement, but cauliflower type morphological performance is more evident here in terms of several trials. © 2019 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/2.0961912jes]
Manuscript submitted May 3, 2019; revised manuscript received June 14, 2019. Published July 19, 2019.
Due to the advent of current energy demand and to reduce the global rise of carbon dioxide, the application of non- renewable energy sources are gaining momentum worldwide. Out of the non -renewable energy sources, the conversion of solar energy into chemical energy in the form of high energy density molecule such as hydrogen via water splitting reaction is the cornerstone of the current research mandate. In this respect, artificial photosynthesis research is an active research area from the last two decades. A special type of electrochemical cells was developed, which is termed as Photoelectrochemical cell or PEC cells to carry out this. It is to be mentioned here that; hydrogen is the fuel of choice due to its green nature1 for a sustainable near future energy demand. For obtaining a good STH (solar – to -hydrogen) efficient system, the development of working photoelectrode, in this case, is getting paramount importance. For instance, metal oxides based photoanode materials such as TiO2, ZnO have been developed for converting the incident photon into a storable energy form with the generation of hydrogen photoelectrochemically.2,3 However, the performance of such electrode system in under the threshold and therefore, the search for sustainable, low cost and high-performance photoelectrode materials for solar to electrical energy conversion remains an ongoing hunt.
Apart from the photoelectrode development, photoelectrochemical (PEC) Cell fabrication has been an active area of research with critical analysis mainly focusing on increasing the Solar-to Hydrogen (STH) conversion efficiency and hydrogen storage.4,5 The basic principle of a PEC Cell involves the photon absorption by the electrode, which leads to the generation of charged carrier species. These charged carriers are further responsible for water reduction and oxidation to produce H2 and O2, respectively. In case of a typical n-type semiconductor electrode, the holes generated on photoanode surface oxidizes water molecule at the semiconductor-electrolyte interface whereas, the electrons migrate to the counter electrode and reduce water and thus produce H2.5 The researcher’s interest toward this simple method for production of clean energy has gained importance since the discovery of first PEC Cell by Honda and Fujishima in 19726 for the photodissociation of water into H2 and O2 on a TiO2 semiconductor interface.
One of the prerequisites for the photoelectrochemical water splitting is that the light absorbing photo electrode should possess a suitable band edge position for water oxidation and reduction as well as the bandgap energy should be less than that of the energy of incident photons. For instance, TiO2 displays poorly visible light absorption
zE-mail: debajeet.bora@jainuniversity.ac.in; debajeet1@outlook.com
profile due to the large bandgap of it and hence less efficient for converting the visible light energy into photocurrent.2 Hematite (α-Fe2O3) has emerged out as an attractive and promising photoanode material for usage in photoelectrochemical (PEC) cell7–10 amongst many explored metal oxides. It is considered suitable for efficient absorption and conversion of solar light in the visible range to carry out the watersplitting reaction.11,12 It is due to its high abundance, excellent electrochemical stability properties and an appropriate electronic bandgap of 1.9–2.2 eV, which allows the absorption of light in the visible wavelength region and consequently a potential usage of up to 40% of the solar spectrum. However, due to the short lifetime of its photogenerated charge carriers and short hole diffusion length, hematite has been preferably not an ideal candidate.13 Nanostructuring of hematite (α -Fe2O3), surface modification, and doping of hematite14,15 has been suggested to address these issues. It, in turn, led to increased efficiency of the photoelectrode. It is because their increased contact area with the electrolyte allows efficient transfer of carriers, along with a better solar energy absorption.16–20
Although there are various reports wherein hematite displays different morphologies ranging from microspheres to nanotubes to nanoflakes or nanosheets; but due to the short hole diffusion length, they exhibit low efficiencies.21–23 In 2006, M. Gräztel et al. reported a new benchmark efficiency of 42% at 370 nm and a photocurrent density of 2.2 mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs. RHE at A.M 1.5G sunlight, wherein the authors reported cauliflower type nanoarchitecture and found it for increased efficiency, as the architecture able to minimize the distance of the photogenerated holes between hematite/electrolyte interface.24 Another paper in 2011 by Zhong et al., reports the similar cauliflower turf like structures with a photocurrent of 2.1 mA/cm2. In both these cases, the authors reported the synthesis of the nanoarchitecture by atmospheric pressure chemical vapor deposition (APCVD).25 Hydrothermal and solvothermal methods have been described elsewhere to get cube shaped hematite nanoarchitectures along with flowers,26,27 but there have been no reports regarding the synthesis of cauliflower turf like nanoarchitecture by naive or a secure one-pot method along with the integration of the nano octahedron.
On the other hand, due to increased attention for photosensitization of the solar cell to improve the efficiency by employing costeffective naturally occurring pigments, there has been an emerging trend to utilize the natural dye from the pigment of leaf, seed, and fruit or from a living bacterial cell, by an easy extraction, to obtain environment-friendly sensitizer. Photosynthetic pigments such as chlorophyll, carotenoid, bacteriorhodopsin, and others have an important role in harvesting light and electron transport. Bacteriorhodopsin

absorbs in the green part of the solar spectrum, thus has been studied along with TiO2 nanocatalyst for increasing its light-harvesting capacity and thus increasing hydrogen production.28–30 β-Carotene displays an absorption maximum at 453 and 484 nm31 and hence have been sensitized on TiO2 Solar Cells to study and increase the efficiency32 extensively. Following this, in the current study, we have demonstrated the efficiency enhancement of hematite nanoarchitectures with β-Carotene coating in the form of a 2-fold increase in the photocurrent density magnitude. For the same, we have discussed here also the development of a one-pot synthesis route to obtain the precursor solution to get mixed morphologies of hematite nanoarchitectures: the cauliflower and the nano octahedron.

sections.heading: Materials and Methods
sections.text:
Materials.—The materials used in the present study were procured as follows. Ferric Chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3. 6H2O), Urea CO(NH2)2, Tetrabutylammonium bromide (C16H36BrN) having 97– 99% purity, were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. L - arginine is having 99% purity was purchased from LOBA. Oleic acid, Isopropanol, and Acetone were obtained from commercial sources. These are of reagent grade and therefore, have been utilized as received without further recrystallization or distillation. FTO used for coating of the hematite film were obtained from Ants Ceramics limited, Mumbai, India.
Synthesis of the hematite thin films.—We have synthesized thin films of hematite on FTO in a slightly modified procedure reported earlier.33 As described in Scheme 1, for the synthesis of source precursor, we have taken 1 g of Ferric Chloride hexahydrate and 2.22 g of urea in a round bottom flask containing an oleic acid bath. After this, the mixture is stirred for 2 hours at 210°C, and the aliquot of the reaction mixture was collected after each successive hour. Following this, we have obtained a homogenous viscous suspension which was left for another 24 hr. at 45°C on a hot plate. It was then treated with Tetrahydrofuran (THF) and followed on by stirring for 30 mins to get a Blackish- brown colored suspension. The liquid suspension obtained was used for dip coating on FTO glass substrates, which was further heat-treated at 500°C to obtain the hematite coated on FTO and henceforth the films obtained for aliquots collected after 1, 2 and 24 hours shall be represented as sample 1hr, 2hr, and 24hr.
Extraction of β-carotene pigment from raw carrots and functional surface coating on the thin films.—The extraction of dye was done using a previous report34 and were further purified and confirmed by their UV-Vis spectrum which matched well with the reported literature.35 For the surface coating of the hematite film with the pig-
ment, the films were dipped into the dye solution and were air dried. We have calculated the concentration of beta-carotene using UV-Vis absorbance spectra (Figure S9). By applying Ber-Lambert law, it was found to be 3.97 × 10−5 mol.dm−3.The process was repeated for twothree times to get a slightly thicker coating of the pigment (thickness is not known here), to get them physisorbed on the hematite films and hence, a non-covalent interaction exists between the pigment and the film like it was observed in an earlier case.28 For all HNF with 1hr, 2 hr and 24 hr have been coated with β-Carotene. The modified films will be represented as 1hr β-Car, 2 hr β-Car and 24 hr β-Car.
Characterization.—UV-Vis absorption spectrum was recorded on Shimadzu UV-1800 UV-Vis spectrometer in the range 190 to 1100 nm to obtain information regarding the light harvesting properties. Infrared spectra for the thin films were recorded on a Bruker ECO–ATR spectrophotometer in the range 600–4000 cm−1 to check the absence of organic contents on the as prepared hematite film and to confirm the presence of beta carotene pigment on it. The morphology and composition of thin films were studied using Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM) JEOL model JSM7100F, which was also equipped with energy dispersive X-rays (EDX) spectrometer operating at 15 keV. Powder X-Ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Ultima IV X-Ray Diffractometer, Cu Kα radiation) was used to obtain information about phase purity of HNF films. Thermo Scientific Talos F200S scanning/transmission electron microscope(S/TEM) was employed in HAADF mode, which was equipped with high - resolution S/TEM and TEM imaging along with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) to get a better understanding of the elemental composition of nanoparticles.
Photoelectrochemical characterization.—The photocurrent density was checked an Electrochemical Workstation from CH instruments, CHI660D Potentiostat model with a Potential range of −10 to 10 V and Current range of 250 mA having 3-electrode system configuration with 1 M KOH (pH = 13.6) as the electrolyte. Ag/AgCl in sat. KCl and platinum wire were used as the reference and counter electrode, respectively. The photo-electrochemical cell was custom built from Borosil beaker. The lamp used in this case is a white LED torch light (100 mW) from Tec. Inc. The USA. [TEC LIGHT]. The photocurrent density measurements were done using a white LED lamp with a light intensity of AM 1G. The chopping experiment is performed with the same light source using the in-built light on-off option.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Discussion of the obtained morphology of hematite with FESEM study.—We studied the morphology of hematite thin films obtained

after heat-treatment with Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM). The FESEM Images for the films made from precursor samples 1hr, 2hr, & 24hr from the solvothermal reaction are given in Figure 1. The FESEM image obtained for 1hr is displayed in Figure 1a and, it reveals the early formation of a nano octahedron. However, we have not understood the formation of the cauliflower turf like structure fully, but we observed an even type of distribution from the FESEM image analysis. For the 2 hr films, we found that the nano octahedron and cauliflower turf like structure were distributed uniformly, which is shown in Figure 1b. Here, we also present the dimensions of a nano octahedron, placed inset of Figure 1b, where the distance between two edges of nano octahedron was found to be in the range of 150–180 nm, while the size of each particle in cauliflower turf like structure was found to be less than 100 nm. However, the image obtained for the film of 24 hr displayed only the cauliflower turf like structure as shown in Figure 1c, which is similar to the background morphology observed for 1 hr and 2 hr, but we have found no nano octahedron distributed on them. The specific reason for this observation was not apparent. Therefore, we have carried out here a qualitative preliminary time-dependent study, as shown in FESEM images (Figure S1), to understand the formation and dissolution of the nano octahedron. For the same, the aliquot was collected after 20 mins of the time interval and deposited on the FTO substrate. As the nano octahedron exhibit the formation and dissolution type pattern, we can, therefore, conclude that the nano octahedron structure is less stable compared to the cauliflower turf like structure. The origin of nano octahedron formation takes place during the one-pot synthesis of precursors. It is confirmed from the FESEM study of the centrifuged residue, as shown in figure S2. From the results obtained, it is evident that the uniform distribution of freestanding nano octahedron on cauliflower turf like structures takes place only after heat-treatment.
The effect of temperature and concentration of various starting materials were also studied using FESEM [see the supporting information]. Distortion of nano octahedrons was the common observation for a slight change in any of the parameters, as shown in the FESEM images in the supporting section. However, the cauliflower turf like structure remained uniformly distributed and displayed a higher order of stability at different optimization ranges. The temperature dependent studies helped us to optimize the temperature to 210°C. The role of urea in the reaction was found to remain the same as having been reported earlier.36 However, we have not found any significant role of TBAB here as have been published previously for CTAB, which also acts as a structure directing agent similar to it.37 In the other study, it was found that CTAB also plays a role in forming the parallelepipeds type of hematite nanoarchitectures as described elsewhere.38 To support this, we have collected the aliquot from a none - TBAB mediated reaction and further subjected to FESEM analysis. It revealed no significant change for both types of the thin films in terms of the formation of cauliflower and nano octahedrons, and these remain intact. For a better understanding of the elemental composition of the thin films, we have carried out the elemental analysis in single morphological level for both cauliflower and nano octahedron with HRTEM and Energy
Dispersive X-Ray spectroscopic (EDX) mapping in High – Angle Annular Dark - field (HAADF)mode. The TEM- EDX mapping obtained is as shown in Figure 2, and it shows the uniform elemental distribution of iron and oxygen. We have demonstrated here the TEM -EDX mapping of the individual element instead of mixed mapping to display the absence of any other component. Hereafter, we termed these combined morphologies of cauliflower and octahedron deposited on FTO substrate as hematite nanoarchitecture films (HNF).
ATR - IR spectroscopic studies for hematite nanoarchitecture films (HNF).—We have performed the ATR- IR spectroscopic technique to study the presence of organic functional groups on hematite nanoarchitecture films (HNF). Figure 3 shows the ATR- IR spectra of the thin films coated, for the sample 1hr, 2hr, and 24hr. The spectra demonstrate the absence of C-H vibrational stretching that usually appears at approx. 2900 cm−1, which in turn confirms that the thin films are free from all the organic compounds after calcination at 500°C. The significant vibrational stretching at 546, 583, and 526 cm−1 is indicative of the Iron-oxygen bond formation, and its presence on FTO substrate after calcination. These values are in range and match with earlier reports.39 In the high-resolution FTIR spectra, we have seen a shift in the Fe-O Vibration stretch for 24 hr sample in comparison to the 2-hour sample. But this shift origin cannot be associated with a different form of hematite due to the proper matching of XRD patterns for both 2 and 24-hour samples.
Structural and optical properties of hematite nanoarchitecture films (HNF).—We have carried out the XRD characterization of the HNF for 1hr, 2hr, and 24hr to understand the crystallographic structural properties, and we have illustrated the pattern obtained in Figure 4A. The XRD peaks shown here are in the wide-angle range of 2θ ranging from 10° to 80°. The X-ray diffractograms Bragg peaks are in good agreement with the crystallographic Bragg peaks Si-doped hematite films synthesized by atmospheric-pressure chemical vapor deposition (CVD).24 The diffractogram depicts a more intense peak for substrate whereas less intense peaks for the hematite thin films, which was a common observation in the earlier report too.40 Here we have not observed any significant variation in the crystallographic properties between the three samples as exemplified by the simultaneous increase in the intensity of substrate peak. This observation point toward a small rise in film thickness. We have also compared the relative Bragg peak ratio of the maximum intensities of the substrate to the (110 peak intensity of hematite [I (substrate) /I (110)], as shown in the Figure 4B. It is carried out to see any effect of the formation of two different kinds of morphologies, i.e., the cauliflower and the nano octahedron. But no evidence of crystallographically preferred growth of Bragg planes observed here. We believe the minor change in the ratio is just only a morphological variation rather than the crystallographic one.
We also perform the UV-Vis Spectroscopy of HNF for 1 hr, 2 hr, and 24 hr to understand the light absorption characteristics of obtained morphologies of hematite and Figure 5 represent the spectra obtained for the same. The shape of the spectra obtained is different in all cases due to the measurement in solid state form rather than taking liquid.

The recorded spectra display an absorption plateau at 550 nm, which is in good agreement with the previously reported literature of hematite light absorbance characteristics.37
Photoelectrochemical properties of hematite nanoarchitecture films (HNF).—We have measured the photoelectrochemical characteristics of HNF by running linear sweep voltammograms in both dark and light conditions [LED light: AM 1G)]. Figure 6 represents the curves obtained for different films. In Figure 6a, we present a plot depicting a comparison between the light and dark current densities of hematite films for 1hr, 2 hr, and 24 hr. Here we observe that the dark current density seems to be almost negligible for the HNF, whereas,
under the light, it shows a significant increase in the photocurrent density. Here, we have found that the photocurrent density of 24 hr is highest compared to the rest of the samples. It shows a maximum current density of 50 μA/cm2. Concerning the comparison of the photocurrent density, we consider here the current density obtained until the dark faradaic offset happens with a sharp rise in current density. This data was taken at 0.5 V. After this potential; the electrode does not show any effect of the photocurrent density. If one carefully observes the plateau of photocurrent density curve in both 2 and 24 hr., the intensity is higher for the next. To decouple why cauliflower shows better performance than mixed morphology, we need to do a new experiment in a single morphological level, which is now not available in the form

of data. But from previous literature, as reported by Ref. 24, it was found that cauliflower like morphology has a better arrangement of the nanocrystallite to overcome the limitation of short hole diffusion length which usually decreases the photocurrent density.
We have also measured the transient photo response study of HNF under chopped light on and off conditions, as shown in Figures 6b and 6c with different time intervals. Here we noticed that with minimal time intervals, the 24 film shows cathodic transient spike signifies the fast recombination of conduction band electrons with photogenerated holes whereas larger time intervals do not show such a case. However, the falling photocurrent or the transient decay indicates the rapid removal of conduction-band electrons and their injection into the bulk.41 The recombination of these photogenerated electrons and holes with the surface states is the reasons for a spike-like transient response,42 and the falling transient response can be considered as photogeneration of a radical, which acts as an electron acceptor, to rise in spike again.43 From all these findings, we can conclude that HNF having only cauliflower turf like morphology is showing better current den-
sity compared to the ones having both cauliflower turf like structure and nano octahedron morphology.
Functional surface coating of β-carotene on the hematite nanoarchitecture film (HNF β-Car) to see the effect on photoelectrochemical response.—ATR-FTIR investigation of the compositional characteristics of the HNF CAR.—We have used the ATR- IR spectroscopic technique to study the presence of β-Carotene pigment on HNF. The ATR- IR spectra of 1 hr β-Car, 2 hr β-Car and 24 hr β-Car, i.e., the films covered with carotene, is given in Figure 7. Unlike the previous FTIR spectra of 1hr, 2hr and 24 hr films, the β-Carotene coated films showed very significant stretching vibrations ofβ-Carotene which confirm the presence of it on hematite films, as a functional coating. The stretching vibrations 2976.2 cm−1 corresponds to the C-H bond stretch for sp3 hybridized carbon from β-Carotene. A minor stretching vibration at 1384 cm−1 can be assigned to the C - C bond stretch, whereas, the dominant absorption band at 955 cm−1 in the spectrum can be attributed predominantly to the wagging mode of an out-of-plane CH bond. The shoulder peak at 755 cm−1 is generally assigned for the out of the plane bending of the substituted long chain and hence can be concluded as to be matching well with the already reported literature.38 The 512 cm−1 stretching vibration corresponds to the FeO bond stretching. We have compared the ATR - FTIR spectra of both HNF and HNF β-Car to see any changes in the stretching vibration of Fe - O. In the case of HNF 24 hr β-Car, the usual stretching vibration of Fe-O occurred at 512 cm−1 instead of 526 cm−1 as obtained for HNF 24 hr. The obtained shift in the current study seems to be a type of chemical interaction between hematite and β-Carotene. However, to get a more accurate understanding, we will have to do more study.
Photoelectrochemical response study of hematite nanoarchitecture film (HNF β-Car).—Finally, we have measured the photocurrent density of HNF β-Car, and we found a two-fold increase of it as verified by an average number of linear sweep voltammetry scan (Figure S8). It was a common observation when TiO2 nanocatalyst was coated with bacteriorhodopsin.28,29 Figure 8 represents the photocurrent density curve obtained for 1hr, 2 hr, and 24 hr films with and without the β-carotene coating. The comparison of dark and light current densities between the 24hr film and 24hr β-car film is shown in Figures 9a and 9b. The resulting transient photocurrent density of 24 hr β-car under chopped light conditions with different time intervals are shown in Figures 9c and 9d. Here, we have made an inter-

esting observation that after β-carotene coating the transient cathodic spike obtained in case of 24 hr disappear here. It signifies that there is not any bulk electron-hole recombination as described elsewhere44 after coating of β-carotene layer. The reason for the same can be as-
signed to the role of β-carotene as electron donating species in organic photovoltaic devices.45 A simple qualitative understanding of the same will be: the β-carotene here will deliver the electrons generated due to light harvesting action into the conduction band of hematite to fill the additional gap state. Thereby electrons formation from water oxidation reaction on the hematite surface will have a free pathway for tunneling across the conduction band of hematite. In one sense, we can confirm here that the biomolecule such as β-carotene coating helps in faster removal of conduction band electrons. There is also a secondary explanation for the increase in the photocurrent density. The physisorption of pigment has led to an increase in the photocurrent density of the film due to the sensitizing action of pigment. It absorbs the photon to transfer its excited state electron from LUMO into the conduction band of the iron oxide. The light harvesting role and a detailed hypothesis will be following up as a future outlook here.

metadata.abstractText: The enhanced performance of the semiconductor electrode for photoelectrochemical water splitting with the coating of a readily available biomolecule such as the β-Carotene could be the next design of bio photoelectrode. In this work, how the β-Carotene coating on a hematite photoelectrode enhanced the performance of photoelectrochemical response has been described. For the same, a one-pot material chemistry route is described here, with which hematite photoelectrode with combined morphologies of the octahedron and cauliflower type can be obtained. The primary significance of the work is that the β-Carotene coating of hematite cauliflower helps in getting a two-fold enhancement in the photocurrent density in comparison to the uncoated one. Though there are many reports about this type of improvement, however, from the cost wise perspective, the isolated β-Carotene pigment coating and its performance in the current study are better. Also, other main physicochemical prospects are that the β-Carotene coating helps in removing the cathodic transient spike obtained in a transient photocurrent measurement for an uncoated hematite cauliflower. It signifies the electron donating action of β-Carotene to prevent excitonic recombination for this kind of new bio photoelectrode design. In addition to this, the octahedron morphologies with the β-Carotene coating also shows similar enhancement, but cauliflower type morphological performance is more evident here in terms of several trials. © 2019 The Electrochemical Society.
